verses.text: Now a man named Lazarus was sick. He was from Bethany, the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
verses.comment: Bethany was about two miles from Jerusalem. The mention of Mary and Martha sets the stage for the coming sign, as both women play key roles.

verses.text: It was the Mary who anointed the Lord with perfume and wiped His feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.
verses.comment: This anticipates the later story in John 12, identifying Mary with great honor—a reminder of the value given to loving devotion.

verses.text: So the sisters sent a message to Him, saying, 'Lord, the one You love is sick.'
verses.comment: The term 'the one You love' reveals the special relationship Jesus shared with Lazarus, pointing to the personal nature of Christ's ministry.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, He said, 'This sickness will not end in death. Rather, it is for the glory of God, so that the Son of God may be glorified through it.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to a prophetic purpose behind the suffering; this is a high christological claim, placing Himself at the center of God's glorification (see John 17:1).

verses.text: Now Jesus loved Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus.
verses.comment: The word 'loved' is agapao in Greek, stressing deep, selfless love—Jesus' love is for all members of the household, showing the importance of family and community in the life of faith.

verses.text: So when He heard that Lazarus was sick, He stayed two days longer in the place where He was.
verses.comment: Jesus' delay is intentional—His timing aligns with God's plan, not human expectation. This foreshadows the way God's providence often works beyond our understanding.

verses.text: Then after this He said to the disciples, 'Let us go back to Judea.'
verses.comment: Returning to Judea means facing danger (see v.8), yet Jesus' commitment illustrates His courage and mission focus.

verses.text: The disciples said to Him, 'Rabbi, the Jews were just now seeking to stone You, and are You going there again?'
verses.comment: The disciples recall the hostility of the authorities, highlighting the risk in Jesus' decision—His obedience is total.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Are there not twelve hours in the day? If anyone walks in the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to the fixed time of His mission—the 'light' refers both to physical light and His own light as the true Light of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: But if anyone walks in the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him.'
verses.comment: Spiritually, this warns about living outside of God's guidance. Christ is the Light in whom believers are to walk.

verses.text: After He said these things, He told them, 'Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep, but I am going there to wake him up.'
verses.comment: To 'fall asleep' was a common Jewish euphemism for death, but Jesus will literally wake Lazarus—He has authority over death.

verses.text: The disciples said to Him, 'Lord, if he has fallen asleep, he will recover.'
verses.comment: The disciples misunderstand Jesus, thinking Lazarus is only resting, not dead.

verses.text: Now Jesus had spoken about his death, but they thought He meant natural sleep.
verses.comment: The clarification shows John's concern for accurate understanding—Jesus’ words often contain deeper spiritual meanings.

verses.text: So Jesus told them plainly, 'Lazarus is dead.'
verses.comment: Jesus is direct. He faces death with clarity and the power to reverse it.

verses.text: 'And for your sake I am glad I was not there, so that you may believe. But let us go to him.'
verses.comment: Jesus desires to strengthen His disciples’ faith through this miracle, which is a sign pointing to His own resurrection.

verses.text: Then Thomas, called the Twin, said to his fellow disciples, 'Let us also go, that we may die with Him.'
verses.comment: Thomas demonstrates loyalty, though tinged with pessimism—his words highlight discipleship’s call to follow Christ even in danger.

verses.text: When Jesus arrived, He found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb for four days.
verses.comment: The four days indicate that Lazarus was really dead—Jewish tradition held that the soul could linger for three days before departing.

verses.text: Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, about two miles away.
verses.comment: This proximity underlines the miracle’s public nature—many witnesses from Jerusalem would be present.

verses.text: Many of the Jews had come to Martha and Mary to comfort them concerning their brother.
verses.comment: This custom shows the importance of shared grief and communal support in times of loss.

verses.text: When Martha heard that Jesus was coming, she went out to meet Him, but Mary stayed in the house.
verses.comment: Martha’s active nature is consistent with her characterization elsewhere. Mary’s posture hints at reflective devotion.

verses.text: Martha said to Jesus, 'Lord, if You had been here, my brother would not have died.'
verses.comment: Martha expresses faith in Jesus’ power and sorrow at His absence. Her words suggest that she believes Jesus could have healed Lazarus.

verses.text: But even now I know that whatever You ask from God, God will give You.'
verses.comment: Martha’s faith extends beyond hope for the future, showing she believes in Jesus’ unique relationship with the Father.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Your brother will rise again.'
verses.comment: A direct promise, with both literal (immediate) and eschatological (final resurrection) meaning (see John 5:28-29).

verses.text: Martha said to Him, 'I know that he will rise again in the resurrection at the last day.'
verses.comment: Her hope is based on Jewish belief in the general resurrection, especially as expressed in Daniel 12:2.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'I am the resurrection and the life. Whoever believes in Me, though he die, yet shall he live.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims He is not only the agent of resurrection but its very source—a claim to divinity (see John 14:6). His words teach the spiritual reality of eternal life in Him.

verses.text: 'And everyone who lives and believes in Me shall never die. Do you believe this?'
verses.comment: Another promise of spiritual eternal life. This alludes to the indestructible life believers have in union with Christ.

verses.text: She said to Him, 'Yes, Lord; I believe that You are the Messiah, the Son of God, who is coming into the world.'
verses.comment: Martha's confession is highly christological, matching Peter's confession (Matt. 16:16). She recognizes Jesus as the Messiah and Son of God.

verses.text: When she had said this, she went and called her sister Mary, saying in private, 'The Teacher is here and is calling for you.'
verses.comment: Referring to Jesus as 'Teacher' reveals His role in forming disciples—He is the authoritative Teacher.

verses.text: And when she heard it, Mary got up quickly and went to Him.
verses.comment: Mary’s eagerness shows her devotion and the compelling presence of Christ.

verses.text: Now Jesus had not yet come into the village, but was still at the place where Martha had met Him.
verses.comment: The meeting takes place outside the village, indicating both privacy and the significance of the coming miracle.

verses.text: When the Jews who were with her in the house, consoling her, saw Mary get up quickly and go out, they followed her, supposing she was going to the tomb to weep there.
verses.comment: This brings witnesses to the miracle, reinforcing the public reality of Lazarus’s condition.

verses.text: Now when Mary reached the place where Jesus was and saw Him, she fell at His feet and said, 'Lord, if You had been here, my brother would not have died.'
verses.comment: Mary’s words echo Martha’s. Her act of falling at Jesus’ feet shows deep reverence—a model of worship and surrender.

verses.text: When Jesus saw her weeping, and the Jews who had come with her also weeping, He was deeply moved in His spirit and troubled.
verses.comment: The Greek for 'deeply moved' is strong—Jesus experiences powerful compassion, showing that God is not distant but grieves with us.

verses.text: 'Where have you laid him?' He asked. They said to Him, 'Lord, come and see.'
verses.comment: This exchange is both relational and practical—Jesus identifies with human grief and loss.

verses.text: Jesus wept.
verses.comment: The shortest verse in Scripture. It shows Jesus’ full humanity: He grieves with His friends, fulfilling the role of our perfect High Priest who shares our sorrows (see Heb. 4:15).

verses.text: So the Jews said, 'See how He loved him!'
verses.comment: Christ’s love is unmistakable to all around Him. It reveals the depth of His friendship and His willingness to enter into our pain.

verses.text: But some of them said, 'Could not He who opened the eyes of the blind man also have kept this man from dying?'
verses.comment: There is wonder and doubt among the crowd. They reference a prior miracle (John 9) with the blind man—highlighting growing public awareness of Jesus’ works.

verses.text: Then Jesus, deeply moved again, came to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone lay against it.
verses.comment: The tomb scene foreshadows Jesus’ own burial and resurrection.

verses.text: Jesus said, 'Take away the stone.' Martha, the sister of the dead man, said to Him, 'Lord, by this time there will be a stench, for he has been dead four days.'
verses.comment: The reality of decay makes the coming miracle all the more dramatic—Jesus’ power reverses the devastation of death.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Did I not tell you that if you believed you would see the glory of God?'
verses.comment: Jesus calls back to His earlier promise. Belief allows one to perceive God’s glory manifested in extraordinary ways.

verses.text: So they took away the stone. And Jesus lifted up His eyes and said, 'Father, I thank You that You have heard Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus openly prays, showing the relationship between Himself and the Father—a model for intercessory prayer.

verses.text: 'I knew that You always hear Me, but I said this on account of the people standing around, that they may believe that You sent Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ prayer is meant as a public witness. The phrase 'You sent Me' is a strong claim to His divine authority and unique mission.

verses.text: When He had said these things, He cried out with a loud voice, 'Lazarus, come out!'
verses.comment: The voice of the Son commands life from death. This is a clear sign of divine power, anticipating Jesus’ own resurrection.

verses.text: The man who had died came out, his hands and feet bound with linen strips, and his face wrapped in a cloth. Jesus said to them, 'Unbind him, and let him go.'
verses.comment: Contrasts with Jesus' own resurrection, where grave cloths are left behind. The community’s role in unbinding is significant—the ministry of bringing freedom is often communal.

verses.text: Many of the Jews therefore, who had come with Mary and had seen what He did, believed in Him.
verses.comment: Many witnesses come to faith through Jesus’ miraculous works—faith often grows where God's power is visibly present.

verses.text: But some of them went to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.
verses.comment: Divided responses to miracles are common in the Gospels—some believe, others report to authorities.

verses.text: So the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered the council and said, 'What are we to do? For this man performs many signs.'
verses.comment: The council refers to the Sanhedrin. The leaders recognize the scale of Jesus’ miracles but respond with fear rather than faith.

verses.text: 'If we let Him go on like this, everyone will believe in Him, and the Romans will come and take away both our place and our nation.'
verses.comment: 'Our place' references the temple. The leaders worry about political consequences of mass belief in Jesus.

verses.text: But one of them, Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, said to them, 'You know nothing at all,
verses.comment: Caiaphas was the high priest; his words will have deeper spiritual meaning than he realizes.

verses.text: 'You do not realize that it is better for you that one man should die for the people, not that the whole nation should perish.'
verses.comment: Caiaphas speaks with political motivation, but his words fulfill prophecy about the Messiah’s atoning death (Isaiah 53:8).

verses.text: He did not say this from himself, but as high priest that year he prophesied that Jesus would die for the nation,
verses.comment: Unwittingly, the high priest speaks for God—showing God can use even those opposed to His purposes.

verses.text: and not for the nation only, but also to gather into one the children of God who are scattered abroad.
verses.comment: The unity of God's children is part of Jesus’ saving work. The spiritual interpretation sees one unified people of God drawn together from every nation.

verses.text: So from that day on they plotted to kill Him.
verses.comment: The plot against Jesus intensifies—fulfilling both human opposition and divine providence. His death is not accidental but divinely purposed.

verses.text: Jesus therefore no longer walked openly among the Jews but went from there to a region near the wilderness, to a town called Ephraim, and He stayed there with the disciples.
verses.comment: Jesus withdraws to prepare for the final Passover. The pattern of withdrawal and return is notable in His ministry.

verses.text: Now the Passover of the Jews was at hand, and many went up from the country to Jerusalem before the Passover to purify themselves.
verses.comment: The reference to purification before Passover reflects the Jewish concern for ritual purity; this sets the context for Jesus’ death as the true Passover sacrifice.

verses.text: They were looking for Jesus and were saying to one another as they stood in the temple, 'What do you think? Will He not come to the feast at all?'
verses.comment: The anticipation of Jesus’ arrival builds suspense for the following events.

verses.text: Now the chief priests and the Pharisees had given orders that if anyone knew where He was, he should tell them, so that they might arrest Him.
verses.comment: The plot is explicit: Jesus’ arrest is sought by the religious authorities, wrapping the chapter with mounting hostility before the Passion narrative.
